properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran.

  •  Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings and providing advice to relevant authorities. 
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 02/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Incident Location: Cape Conran
Issue Date: Wednesday 27 December 2023, 11:38 am
Next Update: Tuesday 02 January 2024, 12:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31729/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran.

-  Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
- A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
- While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area. 


Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang
properties.webBody:
MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT LODDON WEIR D/S
  • No significant rainfall has been observed in the 24 hours to 9:00 am Thursday. 
  • No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. 
  • River levels are elevated across the Loddon River catchment from recent rainfall.
Loddon Weir to Kerang:
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Loddon River at Loddon Weir D/S. As of 10:00 am Thursday the level is 4.45 m, above the minor level (3.30 m).
  • The Loddon River at Appin South is currently at 0.30 metres and steady, below the minor flood level (2.80 m) The Loddon River at Appin South is expected to remain below the minor flood level (2.80 m) during Thursday and Friday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Check VicTraffic for road closures and always follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 29/12/2023 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

Minor flooding occurring downstream of Basin Creek

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Thursday, rainfall totals of 5-13 mm have been observed in the Snowy River catchment. Showers are forecast for the remainder of Wednesday and Thursday.

River levels are elevated across the Snowy River catchment from recent rainfall.

Please note that flood class levels at Jarrahmond, McKillops Bridge, Buchan, and Orbost have been updated to better reflect flood impacts along the Snowy River. Please refer to Victorian Flood Class Levels South of Divide (bom.gov.au) for current flood class levels.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Decide what you and your family will do if flooding impacts you. For information on how to prepare go to www.ses.vic.gov.au/get-ready/floodsafe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Areas around rivers and streams may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 29/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Bunyip River downstream of Iona.

The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 15 mm since 09:00 AM Wednesday 27 December 2023. The Western Port catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 1 mm for the same period. Rainfall totals of 0 to 2 mm is forecast for the catchment Thursday 28 December 2023.

The level of the Bunyip River at Cora Lynn is currently at 3.33 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (3.10 metres) and falling. It peaked this morning at 3.696 metres, above the Minor Flood Level (3.10 metres).

Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn remains closed to traffic and will remain closed overnight. River level will be assessed early tomorrow morning to determine If gates can be opened.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Cyclists and walkers should be wary of tracks next to rivers
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 29/12/2023 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Avoca River to Charlton Town

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT CHARLTON TOWN AND CHARLTON DOWNSTREAM
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Avoca River at Charlton Town as river levels continue to fall slowly.
  • Moderate flooding peaked downstream of Charlton Town during Wednesday and river levels are falling.
  • No significant rainfall has been recorded since 9:00 am Thursday and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.
Avoca River to Charlton Town:
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Avoca River to Charlton Town.
  • The Avoca River at Charlton Town is currently at 4.26 metres and falling slowly, above the minor flood level. The Avoca River at Charlton Township is likely to remain above the minor flood level (4.00 m) for the remainder of Thursday and into Friday.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 29/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Bunyip River to Iona. 

The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 15 mm since 09:00 AM Wednesday 27 December 2023. The Western Port catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 1 mm for the same period. Rainfall totals of 0 to 2 mm is forecast for the catchment Thursday 28 December 2023.

The level of the Bunyip River at Iona is currently at 1.80 metres, below the Minor Flood Level and falling. It peaked early this morning at 2.135 metres, just above the Minor Flood Level (2.10 metres).
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Drive slowly, obey all roadblocks and never drive through floodwaters.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Avoca River downstream of Charlton town
properties.webBody:
MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT CHARLTON TOWN AND CHARLTON DOWNSTREAM
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Avoca River at Charlton Town as river levels continue to fall slowly.
  • Moderate flooding peaked downstream of Charlton Town during Wednesday and river levels are falling.
  • No significant rainfall has been recorded since 9:00 am Thursday and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.
Avoca River to Charlton Town:
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Avoca River to Charlton Town. The Avoca River at Charlton Town is currently at 4.26 metres and falling slowly, above the minor flood level. 
  • The Avoca River at Charlton Township is likely to remain above the minor flood level (4.00 m) for the remainder of Thursday and into Friday.
Avoca River downstream of Charlton Town:
  • The Avoca River downstream of Charlton Town is just above the minor flood level and falling. Further downstream at Quambatook, river level rises may occur later this week.
  • No river level observations are currently available for the Avoca River at Quambatook. The river level is expected to be below the minor flood level. The Avoca River at Quambatook is likely to remain below the minor flood level (2.00 m) during Thursday. River level rises are possible as upstream peaks arrive.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

What you should do:
  • Decide what you and your family will do if flooding impacts you. For information on how to prepare go to www.ses.vic.gov.au/get-ready/floodsafe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Areas around rivers and streams may be flooded.
  • Check VicTraffic for road closures and always follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 29/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 07/01/2024 06:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:

Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Thursday 07 December 2023, 01:14 pm
Next Update: Sunday 07 January 2024, 06:20 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31401/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
- High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 



Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Burramboot, Colbinabbin, Rushworth, Wanalta.

  • A grassfire which started on December 24 at the corner of Old Corop Road and Guy Road Rushworth has burnt into a large stack of timber. 
  • The fire is safe and will continued to be monitored.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following service can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Services on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Barwon River to Inverleigh.

  • Minor Flooding is occurring at Ricketts Marsh.
  • River level rises are occurring along the Barwon River in response to recent rainfall. 
  • Since 9:00 am Wednesday, no significant rainfall has been recorded in the Barwon River catchment.
  • Showers are forecast for the remainder of Thursday into Friday.
  • This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 5:09pm 27/12/2023.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams. 
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 2:00 pm EDT on Friday 29 December 2023 or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Barwon River to Inverleigh
Issue Date: Thursday 28 December 2023, 01:34 pm
Next Update: Friday 29 December 2023, 02:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31785/moreinfo

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Barwon River to Inverleigh.

- Minor Flooding is occurring at Ricketts Marsh.
- River level rises are occurring along the Barwon River in response to recent rainfall. 
- Since 9:00 am Wednesday, no significant rainfall has been recorded in the Barwon River catchment.
- Showers are forecast for the remainder of Thursday into Friday. 
- This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 5:09pm 27/12/2023.


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for the Buchan River.

Minor flooding occurring downstream of Basin Creek

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Thursday, rainfall totals of 5-13 mm have been observed in the Snowy River catchment. Showers are forecast for the remainder of Wednesday and Thursday.

River levels are elevated across the Snowy River catchment from recent rainfall.

Please note that flood class levels at Jarrahmond, McKillops Bridge, Buchan, and Orbost have been updated to better reflect flood impacts along the Snowy River. Please refer to Victorian Flood Class Levels South of Divide (bom.gov.au) for current flood class levels.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Decide what you and your family will do if flooding impacts you. For information on how to prepare go to www.ses.vic.gov.au/get-ready/floodsafe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Areas around rivers and streams may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • The Buchan Caves Reserve Camping and Cave Tours are closed. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 29/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
  • For relief and recovery information go to www.emergency.vic.gov.au/relief.

This Flood Watch is being issued for the Buchan River.

Minor flooding occurring downstream of Basin Creek

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Thursday, rainfall totals of 5-13 mm have been observed in the Snowy River catchment. Showers are forecast for the remainder of Wednesday and Thursday.

River levels are elevated across the Snowy River catchment from recent rainfall.

Please note that flood class levels at Jarrahmond, McKillops Bridge, Buchan, and Orbost have been updated to better reflect flood impacts along the Snowy River. Please refer to Victorian Flood Class Levels South of Divide (bom.gov.au) for current flood class levels.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

Minor flooding occurring downstream of Basin Creek

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Thursday, rainfall totals of 5-13 mm have been observed in the Snowy River catchment. Showers are forecast for the remainder of Wednesday and Thursday.

River levels are elevated across the Snowy River catchment from recent rainfall.

Please note that flood class levels at Jarrahmond, McKillops Bridge, Buchan, and Orbost have been updated to better reflect flood impacts along the Snowy River. Please refer to Victorian Flood Class Levels South of Divide (bom.gov.au) for current flood class levels.

Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge:
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.
  • The Snowy River downstream of Basin Creek is currently at 3.97 metres and steady, above the minor flood level. 
  • The Snowy River downstream of Basin Creek is likely to remain above the minor flood level (3.50 metres) overnight Thursday into Friday.
  • The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is currently at 4.13 metres and falling, below the minor flood level. 
  • The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is likely to remain below the minor flood level (5.70 metres) overnight Thursday into Friday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 29/12/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Lake Tyers Beach.

  • Due to parts of a whale carcass, there could be an increase in shark activity.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • Signage is located in the area - please follow the directions provided. 
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 5:24 pm on Thursday 21 December 2023.
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • The whale carcass has moved toward Red Bluff surfing beach. 
  • Access to Lake Tyers Beach and Red Bluff surfing beach may be impacted.
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings.
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 02/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

ADVICE - DANGEROUS ANIMAL - Avoid the Area
Incident Location: Lake Tyers Beach
Issue Date: Wednesday 27 December 2023, 11:53 am
Next Update: Tuesday 02 January 2024, 12:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31731/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Lake Tyers Beach.

- Due to parts of a whale carcass, there could be an increase in shark activity.
- A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
- While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area. 
- Signage is located in the area - please follow the directions provided. 
- This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 5:24 pm on Thursday 21 December 2023.


Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
